Peter,
 
Most interesting that you bring up the concept of distance at this time.  I
have been reviewing various metrics of distance and weight in graphs and
have found that many different concepts of distance exist contemporaneously
(in superposition, i.e. step distance, Euclidean distance, other l-norms,
attraction falloff, etc)
 
Novelty can be an outlier in an otherwise deterministic pattern, or it can
be an alternative pattern to a collection of co-variant patterns.
 
I'm having a heck of time getting my head around all of it - especially
spatio-temporal relationships when "LTL" isn't linear ...
 
Which brings me to a question for Ken Stanley:  Coming from UT-A, how much
influence did Ilya Prigogine or Rueben McDaniels have on you and your
understanding of complexity and evolutionary patterns?
 
Seems there is a common thread - but being human I've been accused of seeing
patterns where none really exist ;)
 
Ken Lloyd

(New Paper)



Hi Joal and Ken,

This papers and the results presented there really turned my 
understandings for EC upside down. This kind of search is really 
innovative concept that needs to be explored. But I have several 
questions about it. 

It is obvious that you have to define what is a network's behaviour 
in the task domain and find a way to measure distance between two 
behaviours. I think this is the hardest part of setting up a novelty 
search. For example, in the task domain of maze navigation, you can 
simply say that a robot's ending point is its behaviour, but I can 
argue that this is not all, but the way the robot reaches this point 
can also be considered a behaviour. For example the robot may go from 
point A to point B straight forward, but it can reach the same point 
by going forward and spinning. Your model will consider both as the 
same behaviour while it is obvious the behaviours are different. 

Another thing is that as the task becomes more complex, it is nearly 
impossible to define what a behaviour *is* and how to measure 
distance between them. Consider the tennis playing robot. Or the 
checkers playing network. How can you define the behaviour then? And 
more, how can you measure *distance* between behaviours? It's like 
you have two persons that you know very well and you try to say "the 
distance between your behaviours is 56.1 units"... I don't say it is 
impossible, it is just too hard. 

The simplest approach is to track the network's output pattern and 
have this as its behaviour. But then a slight change will mean a 
different behaviour and the algorithm will end up adding and adding 
more members to the pool, nearly every new thing in fact, thus the 
algorithm will end up as a slightly optimized version of exhaustive 
search. 

But it is really interesting to see novelty search combined with 
CPPN/HyperNEAT on tasks like my biped or just regular NEAT with 
novelty search on the cool demos I saw in DephiNEAT like the Hopper 
and the snake. 

By the way I support the idea that novelty search should sometimes be 
biased with fitness-based search, once a good number of approximate 
solutions is found. Especially in domains where the search/behaviour 
space is vast. 

I believe that the search space that NEAT searches directly (the 
genotype space) is much more big than the behaviour space, simply 
because many many different structures/weight configurations can 
represent the same exact behaviour. The task domain can restrict the 
possible behaviours further, but not in all task domains. But even if 
there are infinite possible behaviours in a space, novelty search is 
still better than random search because it searches explicitly for 
new behaviours, so new genomes that do the same thing will not be 
rewarded. 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "Kenneth
Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Joel Lehman and I are excited to announce our new publication to
> appear in the Eleventh International Conference on Articifial Life
> (ALIFE XI), called "Exploiting Open-Endedness to Solve Problems
> Through the Search for Novelty."
> 
> The paper is here:
> 
> http://eplex. <http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications.html#lehman.alife08>
cs.ucf.edu/publications.html#lehman.alife08
> 
> Direct link: http://eplex.
<http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_alife08.pdf>
cs.ucf.edu/papers/lehman_alife08.pdf
> 
> This paper is about a new kind of search (which works with NEAT) 
that
> abandons the longstanding notion in all of machine learning that the
> gradient of search should be measured with respect to the ultimate
> objective. In other words, it entirely abandons objectives and
> thereby also abandons fitness functions as the impetus for search. 
> Yet remarkably, we still show that such an algorithm can perform
> *better* than one that actually tries to achieve the objective! I
> believe this strange result has fascinating implications for machine
> learning, artificial life, and even biology.
> 
> Lately on this forum we have often discussed the nagging problem 
that
> the fitness function often does not properly recognize or reward the
> stepping stones on the way to the solution. I went as far as
> suggesting that the fitness function can become an *obstacle* to
> success (e.g. when we discussed creativity in Picbreeder).
> 
> While this discussion was largely philosophical, Joel Lehman and I
> decided to make it concrete and actually introduce an algorithm that
> makes an automated evolutionary process in *any* domain behave like
> humans in Picbreeder, that is, like open-ended evolution. This
> approach is called "novelty search." The algorithm simply searches
> for behavior that is novel with respect to what has come before.
> 
> The benefit of this approach is that it is immune to deception 
because
> it does not even try to achieve the objective. I know it seems
> strange but, counterintuitively, we show that in fact it is far more
> effective at solving a difficult problem in a deceptive landscape 
than
> fitness-based search. 
> 
> In other words, what we are saying is that to achieve some of the 
most
> ambitious objectives we might have for evolution, we must abandon
> trying to explicitly achieve them. To quote from the end of our
> Discussion section:
> 
> "In summary, almost like a riddle, novelty search suggests
> a surprising new perspective on achievement: To achieve
> your highest goals, you must be willing to abandon them."
> 
> I believe this lesson is true in practice and is therefore beyond a
> philosophical curiosity. In fact, we are instinctively familiar 
with
> it in life in general when people say things like "You are trying 
too
> hard" or when we focus so much on something so far ahead of us in 
life
> that we forget completely to solve the short term problems that 
stand
> in our way. It is no less true in evolution or search in general.
> 
> For NEAT, novelty search should open up new opportunities for
> discovery that were previously closed off to us. 
> 
> I look forward to hearing your thoughts on this work.
> 
> ken
>
